solution:
From the double angle formula,
\[\cos \left( 2 \theta + \frac{\pi}{2} \right) = 1 - 2 \sin^2 \left( \theta + \frac{\pi}{4} \right) = 1 - 2 \left( \frac{1}{3} \right)^2 = \frac{7}{9}.\]But $\cos \left( 2 \theta + \frac{\pi}{2} \right) = -\sin 2 \theta,$ so $\sin 2 \theta = \boxed{-\frac{7}{9}}.$
gptanswer:
We can write
\[\sin \left( \theta + \frac{\pi}{4} \right) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \cdot \frac{1}{\sqrt{2} \cos \frac{\pi}{4}} \cdot \frac{1}{3} = \frac{\sqrt{2}}{6 \cos \frac{\pi}{4}}.\]Since $\cos \frac{\pi}{4} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}},$ this reduces to
\[\sin \left( \theta + \frac{\pi}{4} \right) = \frac{\sqrt{2}}{3}.\]Then
\begin{align*}
\sin 2 \theta &= 2 \sin \theta \cos \theta \\
&= 2 \sin \theta \cos \left( \theta + \frac{\pi}{4} - \frac{\pi}{4} \right) \\
&= 2 \sin \theta \left( \cos \left( \theta + \frac{\pi}{4} \right) \cos \frac{\pi}{4} + \sin \left( \theta + \frac{\pi}{4} \right) \sin \frac{\pi}{4} \right) \\
&= 2 \sin \theta \left( \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \cos \theta + \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \cdot \frac{1}{2} \right) \\
&= \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \sin \theta + \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \sin 2 \theta.
\end{align*}Hence,
\[\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \sin \theta + \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} \sin 2 \theta = \frac{\sqrt{2}}{3}.\]Then $\sin \theta + \sin 2 \theta = \frac{2}{3},$ so
\[\sin 2 \theta = \boxed{\frac{1}{3}}.\]
